body: What is the version do you use?

> Can you provide error message?

Direct OutOfMemory, because when the number of pages turned over 8,000 pages, according to the information printed by the console, a table checked 80,000 records, resulting in java direct OutOfMemory, and then the situation is that many link link databases directly time out，I think this is a very serious bug.
You can try to create millions of data, and use ordinary paging to query, for example: select * from limit 10 offset 500000, this can directly reproduce the bug, of course, this must happen in the case of sub-tables
i am using the version 4.0.0-RC1, and the index rewrite is also applicable for version 3.1.0.
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

ShardingSphere facing to JDBC layer only, whatever the database connection pool is druid or other.
Monitor is not a JDBC protocol, so we don't know why it can not use.
Can you transfer this issue to druid's GitHub repo and try to analyze which JDBC protocol is not support first?
I will close this issue soon if no further question.
I will close this issue soon if no further question.

Thanks.

It works normal when I modified sharding-jdbc config:
```yaml
  shardingsphere:
    datasource:
      names: ds
      ds:
        type: com.alibaba.druid.pool.DruidDataSource
        driverClassName: com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
        url: jdbc:mysql://172.31.53.4:3306/phonerobot-outbound?useSSL=false&useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF-8
        username: root
        password: iflytek
        filters: stat,wall,slf4j
        druid:
          initialSize: 5
          minIdle: 5
          maxActive: 50
          maxWait: 60000
          timeBetweenEvictionRunsMillis: 60000
          minEvictableIdleTimeMillis: 30000
          validationQuery: SELECT 'x' FROM DUAL
          testWhileIdle: true
          testOnBorrow: false
          testOnReturn: false
          poolPreparedStatements: true
          maxPoolPreparedStatementPerConnectionSize: 20
          #filters: stat,wall,slf4j
          connectionProperties: druid.stat.mergeSql=true;druid.stat.slowSqlMillis=5000   
```

> # DATASOURCE (DataSourceAutoConfiguration & DataSourceProperties)
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.names=ds_master
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.type=org.apache.tomcat.jdbc.pool.DataSource
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.driver-class-name=com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.url= 
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.username= 
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.password= 
spring.shardingsphere.datasource.ds_master.max-total=100
spring.shardingsphere.props.sql.show=true

# JPA (JpaBaseConfiguration, HibernateJpaAutoConfiguration)
spring.jpa.database = MYSQL
spring.jpa.hibernate.ddl-auto = update
spring.jpa.properties.hibernate.dialect = org.hibernate.dialect.MySQL5Dialect
spring.data.jpa.repositories.enabled=true
spring.jpa.open-in-view=false
spring.jpa.show-sql=true

spring.shardingsphere.sharding.default-data-source-name=ds_master

spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.key-generator.column=id
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.key-generator.type=SNOWFLAKE
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.key-generator.props.worker.id=123
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.key-generator.props.max.tolerate.time.difference.milliseconds=0
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.table-strategy.actual-data-nodes=ds_master.ENTITY_INFO_${201901..201912}
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.table-strategy.standard.sharding-column=CREATED_DATE
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.table-strategy.standard.precise-algorithm-class-name=com.yiwu.showme.sharding.config.DatePreciseShardingAlgorithm
spring.shardingsphere.sharding.tables.ENTITY_INFO.table-strategy.standard.range-algorithm-class-name=com.yiwu.showme.sharding.config.DateRangeShardingAlgorithm


> pom.xml
<dependency>
<groupId>org.apache.shardingsphere</groupId>
<artifactId>sharding-jdbc-spring-boot-starter</artifactId>
<version>4.0.0-RC1</version>
</dependency>

notice: what is polluted first is `.mavenrc` file that is added to Jenkins node home directory...
and yes, this script pollutes MAVEN_OPTS...

instead of creating `.mavenrc`, the `MAVEN_OPTS` variable could just have been basically defined before `mvn` command in Jenkinsfile, without polluting Jenkins slave

and `.mvn/jvm.config` way of doing this JVM configuration looks nice, since it will not only be available to Jenkins nodes but also to developers building shardingsphere on their own laptop
This is really an usable and impressive optimization that can help end users a lot，thank you for your efforts
Got it. Thank you very much for the pull request, and sorry about for polluted for other projects.
I thinks you can study groovy script first and try to use the script to calculate the routing result.
I'm pretty sure that `jvm.config` should not have a copyright header and should be added to the rat excludes, because its content is added directly to the `java` executable as is.

> @CalvinKirs Just as @nancyzrh said, this PR only add a maven dependency for jmh, but does not add any test cases yet, so I think you need add test cases for that.
> 
> As my understanding, jmh only can print benchmark info to console which is not very make sense, we have already use jmeter to test benchmark.
> 
> The precondition for introduce jmh to ShardingSphere is we need to auto assert if benchmark is under threshold.

I don't quite agree with your point of view. The existence is reasonable. The microcode test I think needs more lightweight JMH, not Jmeter. The level of action of the two is different. Using JMH will make our committers more convincing when submitting certain code. Of course, it may be my fault. I still want to hear your suggestions or suggestions from others.

> > @CalvinKirs Just as @nancyzrh said, this PR only add a maven dependency for jmh, but does not add any test cases yet, so I think you need add test cases for that.
> > As my understanding, jmh only can print benchmark info to console which is not very make sense, we have already use jmeter to test benchmark.
> > The precondition for introduce jmh to ShardingSphere is we need to auto assert if benchmark is under threshold.
> 
> I don't quite agree with your point of view. The existence is reasonable. The microcode test I think needs more lightweight JMH, not Jmeter. The level of action of the two is different. Using JMH will make our committers more convincing when submitting certain code. Of course, it may be my fault. I still want to hear your suggestions or suggestions from others.

It is absolutely necessary to use Jmeter for large-scale stress testing, which allows us to implement the project with data results as a support. But the microcode test uses Jmeter just like Take not a musket to kill a butterfly.
